Award.AwardTitle: Pilot Program/Travel Grant: Broadening Participation Among Underrepresented Female Students in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation has a strong commitment to broadening participation in engineering among underrepresented groups. Women, especially those from diverse communities, are underrepresented in the engineering workplace as well as collegiate programs that prepare them to work in this sector. To increase representation of women of color in engineering, this project focuses on engaging and supporting high school-aged, underrepresented girls with transitioning from high school to engineering majors at the collegiate level. While the initial program is small in scope, the investigator anticipates that the project will evolve into a national program that will be duplicated throughout Society of Women Engineers' 10 Regions and over 400 sections. The project will allow the Society of Women Engineers to build strong collaborations with public school systems to increase participation of underrepresented girls in engineering.

By targeting third and fourth year high school students, the investigator aims to expose underrepresented girls to cutting-edge, hands-on engineering and technology activities at their local high schools as well as invite them to attend the Society of Women Engineers' national conference to participate in hands-on STEM activities, attend special engineering informational workshops, and connect with engineering professionals and other potential mentors. In closing, the project offers an abundance of opportunities, where underrepresented high school girls will be able to network with engineering mentors and other high school girls who are interested in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the NSF Award #1649313, the Society of Women Engineers (SWE) identified and brought 10 high school girls from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM (in their junior or senior year) and one chaperon each to participate in the pilot program, Broadening Participation Among Underrepresented Female Students in Engineering, at SWE’s Annual Conference in 2016, which took place from October 27 – 29, 2016 in Philadelphia, PA.

SWE’s program successfully identified high school girls who were underrepresented in the STEM profession and that demonstrated an exceptional capacity for leveraging angering and technology skills to solve a local problem in their community. All recipients of the travel grant attended SWE’s major Awards Banquet on October 28 and one was publicly recognized for her accomplishments front of nearly 1,000 professional engineers.

Of the 10 students selected, five identified as Black, Afro-Caribbean, or African American, four were Latino or Hispanic American, and one identified as Native American or Alaskan Native. All recipients were also enrolled in a low-income school (designated by the U.S. Department of Education as having a high concentration of students from low-income families). Students were from Arizona, California, Kansas, North Carolina, New Jersey, New York, Texas, and Virginia.

Through participating in our Annual Conference, these high school students engaged with the then largest conference for women in engineering which drew just over 11,700 individuals (the conference in 2017 was attended by over 14,7000 people). Students engaged in targeted high school programming and attended sessions that promoted diversity and inclusion in engineering for women.

These high school students were matched with various collegiate SWE members to support their experience and to address their questions about majoring in engineering in college and completing the transition from high school to college successfully.

At the Program at WE16, select high school girls and their chaperones engaged in the following activities:

-          Participation in a day-long SWENext Engineering Program offered to area high school girls on Saturday, October 29th. All chaperons will be invited to the Parent Education Program that is held simultaneously.

-          Touring the event on October 28th with collegiate volunteers who will act as guides to the high school girls and their chaperons and bring them to key events throughout the WE16 conference.

-          Recognition at a keynote event to honor each girl’s interest and engagement in engineering.

-          On-going support post-event through free membership in SWENext.

The long-term objective of the program was to increase the pathway of girls both entering collegiate programs and majoring in engineering by introducing them to resources that will provide life-long supports for their achievement in the profession of engineering. SWE successfully leveraged this model of programming into SWENext Global and Local Innovator Awards program, which now has been replicated at our Annual Conference and five WE Local conferences we hold in the United States each year.   

Dissemination:  SWE published its commitment to supporting URM female high school students in persisting and transitioning to college on its website, through its social media, via a press release, and in mass email communications to over 35,000 members (now at nearly 40,000 members). SWE administered a post-event survey that was used to inform its strategic planning in developing similar programs for 2017 and 2018. Our learning in this area will also inform our work with the 50K Coalition and others K-12 outreach work we conduct through our partnerships with other NSF grantees. To view a copy of the press release and blog post, visit here: http://alltogether.swe.org/2016/09/national-science-foundation-grant-helps-high-schoolers-attend-we16/ and http://societyofwomenengineers.swe.org/press-page/504-news-releases/4973-the-society-of-women-engineers-receives-travel-grant-from-national-science-foundation

Intellectual Merit: This project began to address the need to involve female students in engineering prior to college to increase their successful transition to collegiate programs. Through this pilot program, SWE began to document and discover useful strategies to involve girls, especially those from underrepresented and low-income backgrounds, in programming that would support their persistence in the field of engineering. According to multiple studies, girls encounter obstacles at each major transition in their education, from middle school to high school, from high school to college, completing college in an intended major, and from college to career. It is therefore vital that strategies are developed and widely implemented to involve girls in engineering and technology at these different key transition points.

Broader Impact: The broader impact and long-term goal of this project is to increase the successful transition between high school and college for URM high school female students interested in engineering. As noted, SWE used the learning from this project to support its efforts local and national efforts to build programming to support the persistence of female students in engineering and technology throughout their K-12 and collegiate careers and beyond.
